Award.AwardTitle: HRRBAA: Habituation Feasibility Assessment for Critically Endangered Primates

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This high-risk research project will gauge the feasibility of habituating a savanna chimpanzee community at Niokolo-Koba National Park in Senegal in order to explore their foraging, hunting, and social behaviors. Habituation is a process where wild animals become tolerant of humans, enabling researchers to non-invasibely collect detailed, long-term behavioral observations. In the past, habituation has resulted in benchmark discoveries about our closest animal relatives, such as the findings that chimpanzees eat meat and distribute this prized food within their communities, and that females and males use spear-like tools to hunt small mammals. Savanna chimpanzees are of interest because they inhabit risky and biodiverse arid environments that may parallel environments in which hominins evolved. This project will encourage international collaborations among U.S. scientists and Senegalese scientists, local field assistants, park agents, and students, as well as support student training, science outreach, and primate conservation efforts.

Researchers predict that the study of habituated savanna chimpanzees ranging in parkland alongside baboons - their main competitor - as well as abundant numbers of large mammals, such as antelopes, lions, and leopards, will yield important scientific discoveries about their behavior. Fieldwork objectives include: (1) Locating and following unhabituated savanna chimpanzees, (2) estimating the size and composition of the chimpanzee community, and (3) identifying individuals based on their physical characteristics. Given that habituation is difficult, the primary goal of this project is to evaluate its feasibility. The greatest challenges include persistently locating and maintaining neutral contact with savanna chimpanzees because they occur at low population densities and range over large areas. The researchers will make contact at water holes during the dry season and conduct patrols in the wet season when drinking water is abundant. Project personnel will follow international standard guidelines for chimpanzee health monitoring and disease transmission prevention. Habituation feasibility is determined by repeatedly contacting individuals, monitoring their responses to observers during 12 consecutive months, and testing for increasing tolerance towards researchers. Additional goals include improving estimates of chimpanzee community composition and home range. These tasks will be accomplished through supplementing direct observations of chimpanzees with genetic and camera trap methods. If the initial research phase is successful, then the next steps entail closely examining the behavioral strategies of these savanna chimps for surviving in a highly competitive and dangerous savanna landscape.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This study evaluated the potential for longitudinal research on chimpanzee behavior and ecology at Niokolo-Koba National Park in Senegal.  The project provided proof-of-concept that our team can routinely track chimpanzees here to glean scientific data on behavior, population structure, and range use with the support of camera trap and global positioning system technologies. Furthermore, this project developed foundations in physical facilities and human resources to improve research capacity at this remote and rugged field site. This program broadened university participation in U.S. undergraduate student research and mentoring, and provided opportunities for Senegalese scientists and students to cultivate new research trajectories.

The project established quantitative baselines of search effort requirements as well as chimpanzees’ behavioral responses to the search team. Encounters with chimpanzees increased during dry periods when drinking water was scarce. For the majority of encounters, these chimpanzees displayed evidence of curiosity or tolerance towards the search team, indicating high potential to collect systematic behavior measurements with project continuation. In addition, our team encountered 409 fresh or recent sleeping nests, collected 90 fecal samples for future genetic work, and downloaded over 42,000 photos from six camera traps, including approximately 900 photos of chimpanzees.  Observations from chimpanzee nests, DNA extractions from feces, and images from camera traps provide evidence of home range use and population structure, and facilitate the identification of individual chimpanzees.

This program is important to the development of biological anthropology because it enables the study of chimpanzees within a biodiverse savanna environment. These chimpanzees provide information on how great apes acclimate or adapt to extremely hot, dry, and open environments while concomitantly experiencing intense competition and predation pressures from sympatric mammals. Furthermore, the project contributes to the scientific study of protected areas management by conducting basic research on mammal biodiversity that practitioners in wildlife management and conservation can use to determine protected area efficacy. Furthermore, this project contributes to biological anthropology by supporting scientists of color and women scientists.

The project enhanced student research experiences and improved research capacity in Senegal by providing professional development and employment opportunities. Five U.S. undergraduate students gained research experience through internship programs at Purdue University and the University of Southern California, learning skills in big data management, data analysis, mammal species identification, and the communication of scientific results at professional meetings. Project investigators built capacity for primate research in Senegal through deep integration of local scientists, graduate students, and protected area specialists, training 19 Senegalese team members in scientific and safety protocols, and encouraging one-health principles by providing health exams, vaccines, malaria prophylaxes, waste management facilities, and training to prevent disease transmission between humans and chimpanzees.

Longitudinal research on chimpanzees in Niokolo Koba improves species conservation efforts. The West African chimpanzee (P. t. verus) has dramatically declined in population size in recent decades. Rapid growth in extractive industries, particularly gold and iron-ore mining, is the greatest threat to their long-term survival in Senegal. The project bolsters chimpanzee conservation because long-term research is a proven deterrent of illegal activities in protected areas. Moreover, the project provides jobs and health care, demonstrating that local people can make a good living by studying and conserving chimpanzees in Senegal.
